t: On*pn my bed by night I*ln sought him whom my soul loves; I*ld sought him, but found him not.
I*ln will rise now and go about the city, in*ld the streets and in the squares; I*ln will seek him whom my soul loves. I*ld sought him, but found him not.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they went about in the city. “Have*ln you seen him whom my soul loves?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed them when*ld I found him whom my soul loves. I*ln held him, and would not let him go until*ld I had brought him into my mother’s house, and*ld into the chamber of her who conceived me.
I*ln adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem, by*ld the gazelles or the does of the field, that*ln you not stir up or awaken love until*ld it pleases.
What*pn is that coming up from the wilderness like*ld columns of smoke, perfumed*ln with myrrh and frankincense, with*ld all the fragrant powders of a merchant?
Behold,*ln it is the litter of Solomon! Around*ln it are sixty mighty men, some*ld of the mighty men of Israel,
all*ln of them wearing swords and*ld expert in war, each*ln with his sword at his thigh, against*ld terror by night.
King*ln Solomon made himself a carriage from*ld the wood of Lebanon.
He*ln made its posts of silver, its*ld back of gold, its seat of purple; its*ln interior was inlaid with love by*ld the daughters of Jerusalem.
Go*ln out, O daughters of Zion, and*ld look upon King Solomon, with*ln the crown with which his mother crowned him on*ld the day of his wedding, on*ld the day of the gladness of his heart.
